title: React
description: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces.

chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.details: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It is maintained by Facebook and a community of individual developers and companies. React can be used as a base in the development of single-page or mobile applications. However, React is only concerned with rendering data to the DOM, and so creating React applications usually requires the use of additional libraries for state management and routing. Redux and React Router are respective examples of such libraries.

chapters.title: JSX
chapters.details: JSX is a syntax extension to JavaScript. It is similar to a template language, but it has full power of JavaScript. JSX gets compiled to React.createElement() calls which return plain JavaScript objects called 'React elements'. These objects are then used to build the DOM.

chapters.title: Components
chapters.details: Components let you split the UI into independent, reusable pieces, and think about each piece in isolation. Conceptually, components are like JavaScript functions. They accept arbitrary inputs (called 'props') and return React elements describing what should appear on the screen.

chapters.title: Props
chapters.details: Props are a way of passing data from parent to child. They are immutable and are passed from parent to child via attributes.

chapters.title: State
chapters.details: State is similar to props, but it is private and fully controlled by the component.

chapters.title: Lifecycle
chapters.details: Each comphttpsonent has several “lifecycle methods” that you can override to run code at particular times in the process. Methods prefixed with will are called right before something happens, and methods prefixed with did are called right after something happens.

chapters.title: Handling Events
chapters.details: Handling events with React elements is very similar to handling events on DOM elements. There are some syntax differences:

chapters.title: Conditional Rendering
chapters.details: In React, you can create distinct components that encapsulate behavior you need. Then, you can render only some of them, depending on the state of your application.

chapters.title: Lists and Keys
chapters.details: You can build collections of elements and include them in JSX using curly braces {}.

title: Node
description: Node.js is an open-source, cross-platform, back-end JavaScript runtime environment .

chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.details: Node.js is an open-source, cross-platform, back-end JavaScript runtime environment that runs on the V8 engine and executes JavaScript code outside a web browser.

chapters.title: NPM
chapters.details: NPM is a package manager for the JavaScript programming language. It is the default package manager for the JavaScript runtime environment Node.js.

chapters.title: Modules
chapters.details: Modules are the basic building blocks in Node.js. Each file in Node.js application is considered as a Module. It has its own scope, so it does not interfere with other modules or pollute global scope.

chapters.title: HTTP
chapters.details: The HTTP module can create an HTTP server that listens to server ports and gives a response back to the client.

chapters.title: Express
chapters.details: Express is a minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework that provides a robust set of features for web and mobile applications.

chapters.title: MongoDB
chapters.details: MongoDB is a cross-platform document-oriented database program. Classified as a NoSQL database program, MongoDB uses JSON-like documents with optional schemas.

chapters.title: Mongoose
chapters.details: Mongoose is a MongoDB object modeling tool designed to work in an asynchronous environment. Mongoose supports both promises and callbacks.

title: Azure
description: Azure is a cloud computing service created by Microsoft.

chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.details: Azure is a cloud computing service created by Microsoft for building, testing, deploying, and managing applications and services

chapters.title: Azure Portal
chapters.details: The Azure portal is a web-based, unified console that you can use to manage and configure your Azure resources.

chapters.title: Azure CLI
chapters.details: The Azure CLI is a set of commands used to create and manage Azure resources. The CLI is available across many platforms, including Windows, macOS, and Linux.

chapters.title: Azure PowerShell
chapters.details: Azure PowerShell is a set of cmdlets used to create and manage Azure resources. The cmdlets are available in Windows PowerShell and PowerShell Core.

chapters.title: Azure SDK
chapters.details: The Azure SDK is a set of libraries used to create and manage Azure resources. The SDK is available for many programming languages, including .NET, Java, JavaScript, Python, and Ruby.

chapters.title: Azure Resource Manager
chapters.details: Azure Resource Manager is a service that provides a management layer for Azure resources. You can use the Azure portal, Azure PowerShell, Azure CLI, or Azure SDK to manage resources by using Azure Resource Manager.

chapters.title: Azure Resource Manager Templates
chapters.details: Azure Resource Manager templates are JSON files that define one or more Azure resources. You can use templates to deploy resources to Azure, or to validate that a template is valid.

chapters.title: Azure Resource Manager Template Functions
chapters.details: Azure Resource Manager template functions are expressions that you can use in Azure Resource Manager templates to perform operations on values.

chapters.title: Azure Resource Manager Template Parameters
chapters.details: Azure Resource Manager template parameters are values that you can pass to a template when you deploy it. You can use parameters to customize the deployment of a template.

title: SQL
description: SQL is a standard language for storing, manipulating and retrieving data in databases.

chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.details: SQL is a standard language for storing, manipulating and retrieving data in databases.

chapters.title: SQL Syntax
chapters.details: SQL is a standard language for storing, manipulating and retrieving data in databases.

chapters.title: SQL SELECT Statement
chapters.details: The SELECT statement is used to select data from a database.

chapters.title: SQL SELECT DISTINCT Statement
chapters.details: The SELECT DISTINCT statement is used to return only distinct (different) values.

chapters.title: SQL WHERE Clause
chapters.details: The WHERE clause is used to filter records.

chapters.title: SQL AND, OR and NOT Operators
chapters.description: SQL AND, OR and NOT Operators
chapters.details: The AND, OR, and NOT operators are used to filter records based on more than one condition.

chapters.title: SQL ORDER BY Keyword
chapters.details: The ORDER BY keyword is used to sort the result-set in ascending or descending order.

chapters.title: SQL INSERT INTO Statement
chapters.details: The INSERT INTO statement is used to insert new records in a table.

chapters.title: SQL UPDATE Statement
chapters.details: The UPDATE statement is used to modify the existing records in a table.

chapters.title: SQL DELETE Statement
chapters.details: The DELETE statement is used to delete existing records in a table.

title: HTML
description: HTML is a markup language used to structure and display content on the web.

chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.details:
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language used to create and structure content on the web. It consists of a series of elements or tags that define different parts of a webpage, such as headings, paragraphs, images, links, and more. Each element is enclosed in angle brackets (e.g.,

,

,
) and provides meaning and structure to the content it surrounds.

chapters.title: Basic Structure
chapters.details: The basic structure of an HTML document consists of several key elements that define its layout and content. Here's a simple example of the basic structure:.

chapters.title: Sementic Tags
chapters.details: Semantic tags in HTML provide meaning to the web page content by clearly describing their purpose, improving accessibility and SEO.It makes the structure of a webpage more understandable to both browsers and developers.

chapters.title: Title ,Scripts ,Links & MetaTags
chapters.details: In HTML, the <title>, <script>, <link>, and <meta> tags play essential roles in defining the structure, functionality, and metadata of a web page.

chapters.title: Headings & Paragraph
chapters.details:
In HTML, the

to

tags are used for headings, and the

tag is used for paragraphs. They structure the content of a web page, enhancing readability and SEO.

chapters.title: List And Tables
chapters.details: In HTML, lists and tables are used to organize and display information in a structured format.Lists are used to display a group of related items in a structured format.Tables display data in rows and columns, making it easy to compare information.

chapters.title: Forms And Input-Tags
chapters.description: How To Create Forms And Input-Tags
chapters.details: HTML forms and input tags are essential for collecting user data and interacting with web applications. Forms: Define how data is submitted to the server.Input Tags: Collect various types of user data, including text, passwords, emails, radio buttons, checkboxes, and more.These tags form the backbone of user interaction on the web, allowing users to send data to applications.

chapters.title: Id's And Classes
chapters.description: About Id's And Classes In HTML
chapters.details: IDs in HTML are unique identifiers for single elements, used to apply specific styles or manipulate them via JavaScript. Classes are reusable labels that can be assigned to multiple elements, enabling consistent styling and behavior across a group of elements.

chapters.title: Inline And Block Elements
chapters.description: How to Apply Inline And Block Elements
chapters.details: Inline elements in HTML only take up as much width as necessary and do not start on a new line. Block elements take up the full width available, starting on a new line and stacking vertically.

chapters.title: Responsive Web Design
chapters.details: Responsive Web Design is about using HTML and CSS to automatically resize, hide, shrink, or enlarge, a website, to make it look good on all devices (desktops, tablets, and phones)

title: CSS
description: CSS is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML or XML.

chapters.title: Introduction To CSS
chapters.details: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a powerful stylesheet language that controls the presentation and layout of HTML documents. CSS allows for greater flexibility and maintainability, making it an essential tool for web development

chapters.title: Inline Internal And External CSS
chapters.description: How To Apply Inline Internal And External CSS
chapters.details: Inline CSS: Quick, specific styles for individual elements.Internal CSS: Styles contained within a single HTML document for broader application.External CSS: Centralized styling across multiple pages for efficient management and maintenance.These methods offer flexibility in how styles are applied, allowing developers to choose the best approach based on their project needs.

chapters.title: Selectors In CSS
chapters.details: CSS selectors are versatile tools that allow developers to apply styles to specific HTML elements based on type, class, ID, attributes, and relationships in the document structure. Mastering selectors is essential for efficient and effective styling in web design.

chapters.title: Fonts In Css
chapters.description: It controls the typeface, size, weight, style, and appearance of text on a webpage.
chapters.details: Fonts in CSS allow developers to customize the appearance of text, enhancing the overall design and readability of a webpage. By using various properties, you can control the typeface, size, weight, and style, ensuring your content is visually appealing and consistent.

chapters.title: Box Model Margine And Padding
chapters.description: box model is essential for creating well-structured layouts and controlling spacing effectively in web design.
chapters.details: The CSS Box Model is a fundamental concept that defines how elements are structured and spaced on a web page. It consists of four key components: content, padding, border, and margin. Understanding how margin and padding work within the box model is crucial for effective layout design.

chapters.title: Navigation Menu
chapters.description: This basic navigation menu can be customized further with additional styles, icons, or dropdown features
chapters.details: Creating a navigation menu is a key part of web design, as it allows users to easily access different sections of a website. Here’s a guide to building a simple yet effective navigation menu using HTML and CSS.

chapters.title: Positioning  In CSS
chapters.description: positioning methods allows you to create complex layouts and control the behavior of elements in your designs effectively.
chapters.details: Positioning in CSS is a crucial concept that determines how elements are placed in relation to one another and their containing elements. There are five primary positioning schemes in CSS: static, relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky. Each has its unique behavior and use cases.

chapters.title: Flex Box
chapters.description: Flexbox provides a powerful and flexible way to design layouts with minimal effort.
chapters.details: Flexbox, or the Flexible Box Layout, is a CSS layout model that provides an efficient way to arrange items in a one-dimensional space. It allows for responsive design, making it easier to align and distribute space among items in a container, even when their sizes are unknown or dynamic.

chapters.title: Creating Amnimation & KeyFrames
chapters.description: CSS animations by incorporating transformations (like scaling, rotating, etc.) and transitions for more dynamic effects!
chapters.details: creating animations in CSS is a powerful way to enhance user experience and bring visual interest to a web page. CSS animations are made up of two main components: keyframes and animation properties. Below is a step-by-step guide to help you create animations using CSS.

chapters.title: Media Query In CSS
chapters.description: Media queries are a powerful feature in CSS that allow you to apply styles based on specific conditions, such as the viewport size, device type, or screen resolution. This makes them essential for creating responsive designs that adapt to various devices, ensuring a better user experience across desktops, tablets, and smartphones.
chapters.details: Media queries effectively, ensure that your website is both visually appealing and functional on all devices!
